Dear Mrs. Fernandez:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
 How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
 For repeat violations, why the prior CAP did not result in compliance.
 Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action. Please note that
violations of any licensing rules are also violations of the MISEP and your contract.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (616) 552-3662.
LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909

II. ALLEGATION(S)
Violation
Established?
Youth A reported mold in the shower for at least five months, Yes
which he believes is giving him headaches.

III. METHODOLOGY
11/04/2021 Special Investigation Intake
2022C0108004
11/04/2021 Special Investigation Initiated - Letter
Coordinated with SI Team of Consultants
11/04/2021 Inspection Completed On-site
Observed both bathrooms/showers and carpet outside electrical
room in Juhnke Cottage, requested repair invoice, observed crates
of food being brought to cottage by kitchen staff and full
refrigerator; interviewed Youth A, Staff 1 and Supervisor 1, Spoke
with Residential Director 1; observed medication room and
reviewed Youth A's medication log via computer; met two food
services specialists and Director of Food Services.
11/08/2021 Pre-Exit with CA 1
ALLEGATION:
Youth A reported mold in the shower for at least five months, which he believes is giving
him headaches.
INVESTIGATION:
On-site Observations
I arrived at Juhnke cottage on 11/4/21 at 10:45am. Youth A showed me the two
youth bathrooms in the cottage. In bathroom A I observed a substantial amount of
black grime/mildew on the grout between the white tiles on the walls and the ceiling.
In bathroom B there was a moderate amount of grime on the grout on the walls and
ceiling. Both bathrooms had brown/black dirt/grime in the corners of the floor and in
2

the creases at the bottom of the shower doors. The surfaces of both floors had just
been mopped by Staff 1 and were still wet.
Youth A showed me a locked door labeled the electrical room. He said liquid
chemicals leak underneath the door onto the carpet and into his bedroom. I touched
the carpet near the electrical room door, and it was dry.
Finally, Youth A showed me a black loveseat. He refused to sit on it because he said
it was taken from a dumpster and smells bad. The back cushions on the loveseat
were torn and the curtain hanging above it was shredded.
I observed a large metal lockbox attached to the wall intended for youth grievances.
I interviewed Youth A, age 17, privately. He has been at Juhnke since 6/8/21.
Asked who cleans the bathrooms, he said the youth are supposed to clean them. I
asked Youth A why he attributes his headaches to the “mold” in the bathrooms. He
responded, “because when I go in there, my head hurts.” Youth A said he has never
told the staff about his headaches and has not sought medical attention; therefore,
the cause of his headaches could not be determined. He said he was aware of the
grievance procedure, but he has never written a grievance.
I interviewed Staff 1. She has worked at the facility for 10 years but was just moved
to Juhnke Cottage last month. I asked Staff 1 who cleans the bathrooms. She said
the boys or midnight shift staff are supposed to. “I mopped them today with one
young man, but maintenance should get the mold off…Supervisor 1 said he made
several requests.”
I interviewed Supervisor 1. He has worked at Methodist for over eight years.
Supervisor 1 said he has put in “plenty of maintenance requests” to clean the
bathrooms in Juhnke. However, he was unable to produce any documentation
supporting these requests.
In terms of the electrical room leak, Supervisor 1 said it leaked water, not chemicals.
“Someone came a couple weeks ago and fixed it.” CA 1 confirmed the leak was
repaired by maintenance.
Regarding the loveseat, Supervisor 1 denied that it came from a dumpster. “It was
donated. It wasn’t ripped when we got it…A staff texted me that she just went and
bought some curtains out of her own money.” Chief Administrator 1 (CA1) indicated
the facility has already ordered sturdy “behavioral health furniture” for all the
cottages and is waiting for delivery.
3

APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4407 Facility and premises maintenance.
(1) A facility and premises shall be maintained in a clean,
comfortable, and safe condition. The facility shall be
located on land that is properly drained.
ANALYSIS: On 11/4/21 I observed a substantial amount of black
grime/mildew on the walls and ceilings, as well as dirt/grime on
the floors and shower doors of the youth bathrooms in Juhnke
Cottage.
CONSULTATION
Youth should utilize Methodist’s grievance process when they
have complaints that can be resolved internally. RD 1 said she
has recently re-explained the grievance process to staff and
asked their supervisors to have weekly house meetings as
another way to allow youth to express their concerns. RD 1
agreed stating “kids (families and referral sources) need to be
encouraged to use the grievance process” to give the facility a
chance to resolve issues that don’t rise to the level of child
abuse or neglect.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
ALLEGATION:
Youth are not getting enough food in each of the food groups. Staff have bought food for
youth with their own money.
INVESTIGATION:
I asked Youth A if he gets enough food in all the five food groups. He said once he
was served noodles, macaroni, and cheese for lunch. “Sometimes there are no
vegetables or meat,” he added. Youth A was unable to recall any other meal that
was insufficient. “Supervisor 1 will go buy meat if there’s no meat. He makes sure
we got seconds.”
I asked Staff 1 about the youth’s food. “My opinion they don’t give them enough. I
never seen no vegetables or all the right things at breakfast or lunch.” Staff 1
clarified that she was only referring to the last two-week period at Juhnke and not
the whole campus for the past 10 years. She also admitted she is not familiar with
the food types or quantities that meet the nutritional allowances recommended by
USDA guidelines.
4

Before interviews began, two food service specialists entered the cottage delivering
a crate and aluminum tray full of food. This was the day’s lunch and dinner and
tomorrow’s breakfast for the eight youth in the cottage. Staff 1 and two other youths
entered the immediate area. Staff 1 complained aloud to the kitchen staff asking why
there were no vegetables. One kitchen staff unpacked the crate revealing large bags
of cinnamon rolls, bacon, frozen French fries, cheese and cracker snacks, chicken,
pears, granny smith apples, bread, sub buns, bologna, and cheese. The other
kitchen staff opened the door to a full refrigerator containing large bags of lettuce,
salad dressing and red apples from the day before that had not been eaten. She
said the kitchen will not bring more food when what they have is not being eaten.
Youth A then proudly explained to me that “staff try to fight for us to get more food.”
When the kitchen staff left, Youth A removed the foil from his breakfast plate
revealing two sausage patties and a biscuit, then threw his plate in the trash. I saw
Youth K eating a second submarine sandwich for lunch.
I asked Supervisor 1 if he buys the youth food with his own money. He said he will
buy “some extras on weekends while teaching kids to cook, but it’s not because they
don’t get enough food.”
Methodist’s policy does not prohibit staff from purchasing food or other items with
their own money.
I spoke with Residential Director 1 (RD 1) about the food served to youth. She said
complaints from youth at Juhnke cottage about not getting enough is not a new
issue. “The kitchen staff have recently met with the supervisory team at least twice
to resolve this. The kitchen follows the federal guidelines.”
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4149 Resident nutrition.
(2) Meals shall be of sufficient quantity to meet the
nutritional allowances recommended by USDA guidelines:
(www.healthierus.gov/dietaryguidelines)
ANALYSIS: There is no evidence to support that meals served at Methodist
are not of sufficient quantity according to USDA guidelines.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED
5

APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4109 Program statement.
(1) An institution shall have and follow a current written
program statement which specifically addresses all the
following:
(c) Policies and procedures pertaining to admission,
care, safety, and supervision, methods for addressing
residents' needs, implementation of treatment plans, and
discharge of residents.
ANALYSIS: Supervisor 1 admitted he has purchased food with his own
money for the youth in his cottage and that another staff recently
bought curtains. Methodist policy does not prohibit staff from
purchasing items that benefit all of the youth.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED
ALLEGATION:
Youth A did not receive his medication on 11/1 and 11/2.
INVESTIGATION:
I observed the medication room and Youth A’s medication log via computer.
I asked Youth A if he received his medication on the mornings of 11/1/21 and
11/2/21. He said he did not get his medication on those days because his
medication ran out.
I asked Supervisor 1 about Youth A missing two doses of his medication. He said
the nurses who refill medication both recently resigned. According to CA 1, the
Director of Children’s Services has taken on the responsibility of refilling medication
until a new nurse is hired. Additionally in the interim, Supervisor 1 and Residential
Director 1 indicated that if youth require medical attention, they will be transported to
urgent care.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4142 Health services; policies and procedures.
(1) An institution shall establish and follow written health
service policies and procedures addressing all the
following:
(e) Dispensing medication.
6

ANALYSIS: Youth A’s electronic medication log indicates he did not receive
his 8am doses of Concerta on 11/1/21 and 11/2/21.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Repeat Violations
2021C0219034 - intake 4/26/21; CAP approved 6/15/21
2021C0219016 – intake 12/4/20; CAP approved 3/1/21
2020C0108024 – intake 1/22/20; CAP approved 2/19/20
ALLEGATIONS:
The facility is out of ratio in the mornings.
INVESTIGATION:
There were three youth and one staff in the cottage on the morning of 11/4/21 which
is consistent with the required staff-to-resident ratio. Consultant 1 observed the ratio
in this cottage and others on 10/12/21 and 10/27/21 and found the facility in
compliance.
Youth A knew that the required staff-to-resident ratio is 1:4, but he could not recall
any specific instance where the cottage was not in ratio.
Staff 1 works mornings from 6am – 2pm. and said Juhnke cottage is always in ratio
of staff-to-youth.
Supervisor 1 denied there is a shortage of direct care staff in Juhnke cottage. “This
cottage is in ratio,” he affirmed.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4127 Staff-to-resident ratio.
(3) The ratio formula for direct care workers shall
correspond with the institution's purpose and the needs of
the residents and shall assure the continual safety,
protection, and direct care and supervision of residents.
7

ANALYSIS: The ratio of staff-to-residents is 1:4. On 10/12/21, 10/27/21 and
11/04/21, licensing consultants observed Juhnke Cottage was
compliant with this rule.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Once an acceptable corrective action plan is received, I recommend this facility
continue its current licensing status.
November 9, 2021
